etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in John Dee (1527–1609), mathematician, astrologer, and antiquary. From post-classical Latin staticus static + -al

definitions: Involving or relating to the measurement of weight or the use of a balance; = "static".

notes.text: "statical baroscope" noun Obsolete a baroscope in which the varying pressure of the air was rendered observable by the movements of a balance. "statical chair" noun now historical and rare the weighing chair devised by Santorio Santori.

definitions: Originally: †relating to weight or the equilibrium of weight (obsolete). In later use: of or relating to forces in equilibrium or the condition of rest in objects or structures; (of forces) acting to produce or maintain equilibrium; (hence) of or relating to the science of statics.

Of, relating to, or designating a fixed or stable condition, as distinguished from a state of progress or change. Also: that is in such a condition; constant, invariable. Compare "static". Now chiefly Sociology.
